content: Yes, there are a few things that you should avoid doing that might make your loved one's experience worse. 1. Arguing or correcting: People with Alzheimer's may forget important details, repeat themselves, or become confused. Correcting them or arguing with them can cause feelings of frustration, confusion, and aggression. 2. Rushing or hurrying: People with Alzheimer's may need extra time to complete tasks or make decisions. Rushing or hurrying them can cause feelings of anxiety and stress. 3. Overstimulating: While sensory stimulation can be beneficial, too much stimulation can be overwhelming and cause confusion and agitation. 4. Ignoring their feelings: People with Alzheimer's may experience a wide range of emotions, including sadness, frustration, and anxiety. Ignoring or dismissing their feelings can cause them to feel isolated and misunderstood. 5. Being overly critical: People with Alzheimer's may struggle with tasks and it is important to be patient and encouraging. Being overly critical or negative can lead to feelings of inadequacy and low self-esteem. Remember, every person with Alzheimer's experiences the disease differently, so it is important to be adaptable and responsive to their individual needs. Being patient, kind, and understanding can go a long way in making their experience a little bit easier.
